awd_titl_txt: DDRIG in DRMS: Social preference and voluntary donation to climate mitigation.
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate change is a worldwide threat, importantly this means it threatens both the individual and humanity more broadly. According to the most recent IPCC report, we have to immediately and rapidly reach net zero carbon emissions to avoid many of the worst effects. Determining how to motivate the public to pursue carbon mitigation will therefore be essential for policy makers. This project studies the value, known as willingness to pay (WTP), placed on climate change mitigation in an experimental setting. In particular this project is interested if the way information about climate change is presented to people (framing), and people’s preferences on the distribution of income (social preferences), impact their WTP. Further, this project also studies if an individual’s social preferences changes the impact of framing. 

The framing used in this experiment mirrors one of the real world characteristics of climate change. Developed nations pollute the most per capita, but developing nations are the most exposed to climate change. Thus, some participants will receive framing emphasizing the risks from climate change to themselves directly, whereas others will receive language emphasizing the risk to those in developing nations. It is hypothesized that the former framing may be more motivating to self-regarding individuals, whereas individuals who are more strongly concerned with other’s welfare will be more motivated by the latter framing.  Results from this experiment will become part of the literature seeking to inform active and ongoing policy discussions. For example, this project’s findings are be of use to policy makers trying to word a referendum. Environmental activists engaged in outreach such as deep conversation may also find the results helpful in tailoring their messages.

por.por_cntn:
One of the surprising things about climate change from a public policy perspective is that despite the urgency, there has been relatively little definitive action to address it. Polls suggest that Americans favor action on climate change. At the same time, as recently as 2018 a carbon tax was voted down in a Washington State referendum. This study seeks to explain some factors behind the disconnect between interest in climate change and lack of action to mitigate it.

One possible explanation is that people may have specific ideas over how money should be distributed, sometimes called social preferences. Curbing CO2 emissions is what is known as a public good, something everyone benefits from, even those who do not pay. It can also therefore be a way to benefit different groups of people. In the case of climate change this is particularly relevant. Climate change is a global problem with strong distributional implications..In particular, the highest polluters per capita, wealthy residents of developed countries, reap the most benefit from polluting, while people far away or in the future will bear most of the costs. This research explores whether people’s preferences regarding equity are relevant to making environmental decisions.  It also examines whether the way in which information is presented (framing), may interact with these preferences. For example, is it better to point out the personal risks of climate change for the decision maker, or is it more useful to point out risks to the most vulnerable? Is one or the other language more effective depending upon who is making the decision? These are the questions this study was designed to answer.

The basic study design was an incentivized lab experiment. We recruited 245 participants from in and around the city of Corvallis, Oregon in the summer of 2022.  They then came to the lab to participate in an experiment where they earned money for completing simple tasks. After these money-earning tasks, participants completed two other modules designed to try to answer the above questions. The first was a dictator game, where participants divided money between themselves and another anonymous person in the room. This part of the experiment was designed to help sort people into social preference types. Since decisions were anonymous, and no one knew their role, there was nothing stopping someone from choosing to keep most of the money for themselves. Participants who did this were defined as self-regarding. Others almost always chose an even split of money, these were labeled as inequality averse. A final group of participants generally made choices that gave the most money to their partner, and were labeled as altruists.

The second part of the experiment was a contributions task. It was designed to see if the identified types made different decisions around reducing CO2 emissions. Roughly half of participants were told only about the science of climate change (control framing). A quarter were also told about how climate change impacts developing countries with a picture of a forest fire in Brazil for emphasis (global framing). The remaining quarter were told about the effects of climate change on Oregon, again with an accompanying picture of a forest fire in Oregon (local framing). Once everyone had been given this information, they chose how much of their earned money they wanted to give to the purchase of cap-and-trade permits. We expected that different framing might have more of an effect on participants with different social preferences.

One implication of this study is that policy makers concerned with climate change may need to tailor their message to specific audiences. Trying to limit the message to the scientific facts is likely to be the least motivating framing. Instead, this result suggests an environmental justice message may be compelling to some persuadable individuals. Re-framing a proposed carbon tax initiative to focus on this issue might help garner the necessary public support to pass it.
